issue.title: False positive undefined-variable when a function attribute of same name is set

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce
```python
CONDITION = None
FUNC = lambda: CONDITION
FUNC.CONDITION = 42
```
Pylint output:
```
pylint_bug_repro.py:2:15: E0602: Undefined variable 'CONDITION' (undefined-variable)
```

### Current behavior
An "undefined variable" is incorrectly reported.

### Expected behavior
Zero issue detected when defining a [function attribute](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0232/)
with the same name of a local variable in the current scope.

### pylint --version output
```
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.6.0
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.7.7 (default, Apr 10 2020, 07:59:19)
[GCC 9.3.0]
```

### Additional notes
There are a few other existing issues related to "false positive undefined-variable" errors:
- https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/2491
- https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3688
- https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3791

body:
Here's another case. Interestingly,
```py
x = next(i for i in range(10) if (y := i * i))
print(y)
```
raises this false-positive, while
```py
next(i for i in range(10) if (y := i * i))
print(y)
```
does not.

issue.title: False positive ``used-before-assignment``  for walrus operator different lines

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

labels.name: Assignment expression
labels.description: Related to the walrus operator / assignment expression

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
After the support of the walrus operator, I've noticed that there's still a  `used-before-assignment` false positive when working on different lines:

### Steps to reproduce

Given a file `good-test.py`:
```python
"""Good test example."""
var = f'The number {(count := 4)} is equal to {count}'

```
`pylint` doesn't detect any errors which is expected. However when return to a line like this:

Given a file `bad-test.py`:
```python
"""Bad test example."""
var = f'The number {(count := 4)} ' \
      f'is equal to {count}'

```
We obtain the following:
### Current behavior

Result of `pylint good-test.py`:
```
************* Module bad-test
bad-test.py:2:7: E0601: Using variable 'count' before assignment (used-before-assignment)
```

### Expected behavior

Normally, this should not raise any errors.

### pylint --version output

Result of pylint --version output on my local macOS:

```
pylint 2.7.2
astroid 2.5.1
Python 3.8.8 (v3.8.8:024d8058b0, Feb 19 2021, 08:48:17) 
[Clang 6.0 (clang-600.0.57)]
```

body:
A couple more interesting cases with false-positive behaviour:
```py
print({'key': value if (value := 'something') else 'anything'})
```
 raises `used-before-assigment`, while 
```py
value = val if (val := 'something') else 'anything'
print({'key': value})
```
doesn't. Excepting behaviour - no errors.
Same with classes and dataclasses:
```py
class Dummy:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value

dummy = Dummy(value=val if (val := 'something') else 'anything')
print(dummy.value)
```
raises `used-before-assigment`, while 
```py
class Dummy:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value

value = val if (val := 'something') else 'anything'
dummy = Dummy(value)
print(dummy.value)
```
doesn't. Excepting behaviour - no errors.

issue.title: Add tests for assignment expressions in function defaults

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

labels.name: False Negative ðŸ¦‹
labels.description: No message is emitted but something is wrong with the code

labels.name: Needs astroid update
labels.description: Needs an astroid update (probably a release too) before being mergable

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
- [x] Add yourself to CONTRIBUTORS if you are a new contributor.
- [x] Add a ChangeLog entry describing what your PR does.
- [x] If it's a new feature, or an important bug fix, add a What's New entry in
      `doc/whatsnew/<current release.rst>`.
- [x] Write a good description on what the PR does.

## Type of Changes

|     | Type                   |
| --- | ---------------------- |
| âœ“   | :bug: Bug fix          |
| âœ“   | :sparkles: New feature |

## Description

Closes the first issue reported in #3688

Whenever assignment expressions are used in a function definition they actually get evaluated immediately and are added to the outer scope. This adds tests to test for this. I have fixed this in `astroid` by changing the way `locals` are created from the `NamedExpr` class.

Blocked by https://github.com/PyCQA/astroid/pull/1213

issue.title: False positive ``used-before-assignmnet`` for assignment expressions in class initialisers

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

labels.name: Assignment expression
labels.description: Related to the walrus operator / assignment expression

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Bug description


Same with classes and dataclasses:

```python
class Dummy:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value

dummy = Dummy(value=val if (val := 'something') else 'anything')
print(dummy.value)
```

raises `used-before-assigment`, while 
```py
class Dummy:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self.value = value

value = val if (val := 'something') else 'anything'
dummy = Dummy(value)
print(dummy.value)
```
doesn't. Excepting behaviour - no errors.

_Originally posted by @egormm in https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/3688#issuecomment-924703842_


### Configuration

_No response_

### Command used

```shell
pylint
```


### Pylint output

```shell
`used-before-assignment` warning in the first example
```


### Expected behavior

No `used-before-assignment` errors for the first example.

### Pylint version

```shell
pylint 2.11.2-dev0
astroid 2.8.4
Python 3.9.6 (default, Aug  2 2021, 08:23:35) 
[Clang 12.0.5 (clang-1205.0.22.11)]
```


### OS / Environment

_No response_

### Additional dependencies

_No response_

body: If have created a new issue for the last two issues of @egormm's comments, as they are related to a different message.

body: @Pierre-Sassoulas @DanielNoord I don't think #5213 fixes the original case mentioned here (use of walrus in function default), should this issue be re-opened?
It should be fixed with #5188. I separated this issue in two PR's as they covered different cases.
